*   [![Image 120](https://dynamic-media-cdn.tripadvisor.com/media/photo-o/1a/f6/eb/e3/default-avatar-2020-59.jpg?w=100&h=-1&s=1)](https://www.tripadvisor.com/ClientLink?value=aDVkXy9Qcm9maWxlL0pvdXJuZXkwMzMzNTkyNDc1M19JOE4%3D)      [Journey03335924753](https://www.tripadvisor.com/ClientLink?value=aDVkXy9Qcm9maWxlL0pvdXJuZXkwMzMzNTkyNDc1M19JOE4%3D)1 contribution    0        [A wonderful day but hints on how to avoid any frustration](https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowUserReviews-g155019-d185115-r1022779267-Toronto_Island_Park-Toronto_Ontario.html) I go regularly to the island and love it. Reading some of these reviews I can see that many do not realize a few things. And that can lead to frustration. 

The island is large & has many parts.

So there are three ferry choices Centre, Ward's & Hanlan's. Centre is where the quaint amusement park (younger kids will appreciate )& petting farm is located. And a marina. Ward's includes housing communities and two sit down restaurants. Hanlan's is more remote and includes a nude beach (not everyone partakes so know there are lots of lovely areas here and because not everyone partakes you can be there for hours and many days not see anyone nude. Do not avoid. There are natural barriers to the actual location of the beach location. I went for decades not seeing on nude person. Hanlan's is lovely. 

A bike allows you to use any of the ferry locations and schedules. A bike allows for a better experience. There are bikeshare locations right on the island, look it up. But bringing your bike or renting one off island makes for a more peaceful time. Because you are not time limited. The island itself rents bikes at the back of Centre, including quad trolley like bikes. Walking the island is lovely but it is a lot for some. 

Crowds, even on the most full day there are areas of the island for tranquility. Just hunt them out.

Now the biggest frustration for some - ferries. I always take them and have been in crazy long lines but am fine with it all. Burt some are not & are not with a few people not being respectful with crowds or waiting in line. I personally find the majority of people gracious. 

If you are not okay with crowds and what happens there are many companies that provide water taxis. They will add to your expense but money equals ease & peace. They are not crazy expensive. But they charge each way, ferries are 'free' back to the city. Some are located father down Queens Quay, around Spadina. Google them. There are many options and locations on the island and city back and forth. For some this option will mean a much better day. 

Enjoy everyone. Oh food is not cheap. Not crazy at all, but not cheap. Many families stay for the day and bring food and charcoal to barbeque. My husband and I went with Oscar on the Max Depth Experience, and it was unforgettable! 

It was like navigating an underground slot canyon, with several rappels, some tight crawling squeezes, a cool rappel combo with sort of a zipline meets Tyrolean traverse setup that was EXTRA fun, dropping into sculpted rooms with rippling waterfalls. Even better, when you get all the way to the bottom, you get to rock climb back out! (There are ladders in the harder places, if you want the option for those). It's all safely belayed by the guide, and I side-eyed all the anchors since it's a very wet environment, but they have very solidly bolted anchors and well-maintained ropes. 

Our guide was so cheerful and honestly fascinated by caves, and he talked just the right amount! You learned a lot (even me, who has heard all the normal "cave spiels"!) but you were moving most of the time and didn't feel like it was all "sitting around being lectured at" like a schoolroom. His fun accent just made it all the more enjoyable! He was also really great at making complex rope systems seem simple and smoothly checking everyone for safety without slowing down the adventure or feeling like a safety cop. 

We were able to be down in the caves for over 4 hours and explore very far, with gorgeous crystal formations and one neat trick I've never seen done with calcite that I won't spoil here. Just say these guides know a thing or two that cave guides elsewhere don't! The cave itself was scenic and varied with gorgeous formations. I highly recommend renting the cave suit and boots, which make the experience more comfortable. And bless the rental company for having even my weird sizes so I was comfy all day. I run cold, but I found with a base layer, fleece, and the cave suit I was comfortable for 4 hours no problem. Their rubber boots were also way more comfortable to walk in for that long than I would have guessed. 

This cave company thinks of everything! Love their facility, their equipment, and their guides--this will probably be my highlight memory from my whole trip to Vancouver Island! results.title: 13 of Europe's best under-the-radar summer vacation spots
results.content: Less a city, more a wooded archipelago that happens to host some important buildings, Sweden’s capital is unreasonably attractive – and never more so than in sunny summer, when the sun glints on the water and the many parks beckon. Stockholm has enough cultural attractions to pack several days, from the cobbled alleys of Gamla Stan (Old Town) to exceptional contemporary galleries and museums (including open-air Skansen), while the sleek modern shopping district of Nordmalm offers ample [...] travelers looking to immerse themselves in local culture and language essentials. Language Guides help to let no barriers - language or culture - get in your way.Epic Guides From hikes to bike rides and surf breaks, discover the most epic adventures across the world to inspire your next trip. Epic Guides provide inspiration and first-person stories for a lifetime of unforgettable travel experiences.Pocket Guides For travelers on a short trip that want to make the most of their time exploring. 13 unexpected summer holiday spots in Europe
============================================

![Image 23: Lonely Planet Editors](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2025-05/LPMarkBlue.png?auto=format,compress&q=72&crop=faces&fit=crop&w=64&h=64)

[Save](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/api/auth/login)

 Share 

![Image 24: A suspension bridge spans the emerald waters of the Soca River in Slovenia, aerial view. This spot is a favored destination for kayaking and trekking in Slovenia., License Type: media, Download Time: 2025-02-24T21:44:35.000Z, User: rhylton_redventures, Editorial: false, purchase_order: 56530 - Guidebooks, job: Lonely Planet WIP, client: Lonely Planet WIP, other: Rhianydd Hylton](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2025-05/shutterstock2457854099.jpg?auto=format,compress&q=72&w=1440&h=810&fit=crop)

Spend summer in Slovenia's Julian Alps. Mazur Travel/Shutterstock

Whether you’re sipping a spritz in a buzzing plaza or diving into deep blue waters off a rugged coastline, summer in [Europe](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/destinations/europe) is incredible. But with more and more people joining the fun, some of [Europe’s best places](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/best-places-to-visit-europe) also tend to deal with a bit of overcrowding in the [summer high season](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/best-time-to-visit-europe).

But don’t let that scare you off a Euro trip this year ⁠– there are plenty of lesser-explored corners of the continent just waiting to be discovered. Beat the summer heat in the highest stretches of [Scandinavia](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/destinations/scandinavia) or find an empty beach on the [Baltic Coast](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/destinations/the-baltic-states). Take your vacation where locals go in a lush portion of [Portugal](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/where-locals-go-under-the-radar-destinations-portugal) or flop down on a more relaxed coastline in [Greece](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/discover-where-locals-travel-in-greece).

Whatever your travel style, here are our favorite under-the-radar summer vacation destinations in Europe that are perfect for 2025.

![Image 25: Two adults and a child hike along a path beside a stream in a mountainous region.](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2025-03/Shutterstock497179633.jpg?auto=format,compress&q=72&fit=crop)

Hiking through the Alta Badia valley, Italy. Mostovyi Sergii Igorevich/Shutterstock

1. Alta Badia, Italy
--------------------

**Best for a mountain getaway**

 Advertisement 

If [the Dolomites](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/guide-to-the-dolomites) are the Alps at their most magnificent, the Alta Badia valley in [South Tyrol](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/destinations/italy/trentino-alto-adige) promises the Dolomites at their tastiest. This jagged array of deep valleys, high plateaus and piercing pinnacles in northern [Italy](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/destinations/italy/) echoes with poignant history: between 1915 and 1918, Italian and Austro-Hungarian forces fought amid these unforgiving peaks, and today you can hike routes such as the Kaiserjäger to see their trenches and gun emplacements. Alta Badia is renowned for its skiing, but in summer the cable cars and mountain huts reopen to serve hungry hikers, cyclists, paragliders and trail runners instead – the region is spangled with Michelin stars, but even simple refuges dish up good-value but top-notch cuisine (think mountain cheeses, pasta and strudels). For an extra adrenaline buzz, tackle the challenging _via ferrata_("iron road") climbs, a method of traversing vertiginous rock faces via rungs and cables.

**Planning tip:**The nearest airports are at Innsbruck, Verona and Venice. La Villa, San Cassiano (St Kassian) and Corvara make excellent bases from which to explore the peaks and valleys.

![Image 26: A village clings to a hill rising from the banks of a river with rugged green hills beyond.](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2024-10/GettyRF489525152.jpg?auto=format,compress&q=72&fit=crop&ar=1:1&w=450&h=450)

![Image 27: A terracotta bowl filled with sausage, kale and potato soup. ](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2024-08/GettyImages-553198563.jpg?auto=format,compress&q=72&fit=crop&ar=4:3&w=800&h=600)

**Left:** The Minho region of Portugal. Sergey Peterman/Getty Images **Right:** Caldo verde, a traditional soup from the Minho region. Westend61/Getty Images

2. Minho, Portugal
------------------

**Best for foodies**

Where do the Portuguese take their vacations in Portugal? Those in the know savor staycations in the birthplace of the kingdom: [the northerly Minho region](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/portugal/the-minho), a land of verdant hills, traditional culture and fabulous flavors. The Minho is noted for its vinho verde, literally "green wine", released just a few months after harvest. As well as those fruity drops (Loureiro and Alvarinho are our picks), the cuisine is delectable, too. There are plenty of local specialties. In Ponte de Lima, Portugal’s oldest town, find a restaurant overlooking the Roman bridge and savor arroz de sarrabulho – rice cooked in pig’s blood and studded with various pork morsels (tastier than it sounds) – and caldo verde, a hearty kale soup. Monkfish, sea bass and bream are fish favorites, along with _bacalhau_– salt cod, a staple throughout the country. Work up an appetite strolling historic towns such as[Braga](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/portugal/the-north/braga), Guimarães and Viana do Castelo, where magnificently diverse architecture recalls the wealth of adventurous merchants who made their fortunes during the Age of Discovery and in the subsequent colonial era.

**Trip plan:** Porto is a one-hour train ride from Braga, from where buses serve other towns in the Minho.

![Image 28: A building with a wave-like roof structure and chapel-like entrance at the foot of some mountains.](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2025-03/Shutterstock2182274447.jpg?auto=format,compress&q=72&fit=crop)

Ysios winery, Calatrava. JJFarq/Shutterstock

3. La Rioja, Spain
------------------

**Best for wine lovers**

The compact region of [La Rioja](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/spain/la-rioja) somehow crams 500-plus wineries into its modest area, between [Bilbao](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/spain/aragon-basque-country-and-navarra/bilbao), [Zaragoza](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/destinations/spain/aragon-basque-country-and-navarra/zaragoza) and [Madrid](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/spain/madrid) in northern [Spain](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/destinations/spain/). In summer, the vineyards striping the craggy Ebro River Valley are verdant and lush, and among them you’ll find traces of past settlers – remains betray inhabitation from Neolithic times, through Moorish occupation to medieval Christian settlement. This is a slow-paced region, rich in history and viticulture: tastings are a must. Visit the venerable, château-style wineries clustered around Haro in the Rioja Alta; elsewhere, Rioja Alavesa is more contemporary – architects Gehry and Calatrava had a hand in the design of Marqués de Riscal and Ysios wineries. Logroño, La Rioja’s capital, is packed with bars serving cheap, tasty pintxos (tapas), ideal for soaking up the fruity reds. Summers can be very hot, so plan accordingly.

**Planning tip:** Make a leisurely loop around La Rioja. Visit Haro’s bodegas, head east to Briones for its ruined castle and the lowdown on rioja at Vivanco, and do a pintxos-crawl along Logroño’s Calle del Laurel. On the return, stop at medieval Laguardia, below the Sierra de Cantabria; Calatrava’s wave-like Ysios winery is nearby.

![Image 29: A rainbow umbrella is set up on an empty beach washed with blue sea.](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2025-04/Shutterstock1393126436.jpg?auto=format,compress&q=72&fit=crop&ar=4:3&w=800&h=600)

**Left:** Beach on the Pelion Peninsula. Gal_Rotem/Shutterstock **Right:** The narrow-gage Pelion Train. fritz16/Shutterstock

![Image 30: A vintage train rides through lush forest. ](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2025-04/shutterstockRF86659753---crop.jpg?auto=format,compress&q=72&fit=crop&ar=1:1&w=450&h=450)

4. Pelion Peninsula, Greece
---------------------------

**Best for a less-crowded Greek holiday**

Sure, you could bake on busy beaches on a [Greek island](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/best-greek-islands). But in sizzling summer, [head instead for cool Pelion](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/greece/pelion-peninsula), the gnarled finger curling into the Aegean to tickle the Sporades. There’s a range of coastal resorts, mostly more isolated and peaceful than elsewhere: try Horto or Milina on the sheltered west coast, southerly Platanias, or busier Horefto, Agios Ioannis and cute Damouhari near beautiful Fakistra beach on the east coast. The mountainous interior oozes natural and cultural appeal – this is where mythical centaurs came to carouse – with ancient cobbled paths linking traditional villages where you can admire church frescoes, sip grape-based, rakı-like tsipouro in the shade of venerable plane trees, and savor local specialties such as spetsofaï (pork-sausage stew), fasoladha (butter bean soup) and lamb in lemon sauce. Up here, the air’s a good few degrees lower than on the coast, and in summer, you can board the narrow-gage Pelion Train that chugs from Ano Lehonia to Milies, running daily in July and August.

**Planning tip:**The nearest airport is in [Thessaloniki](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/destinations/greece/northern-greece/thessaloniki), a three-hour bus or train ride from the gateway to the Pelion, Volos. Athens and Preveza are alternatives.

![Image 31: A tent glows with green ligh on the side of a lake, with a sky full of stars above.](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2025-04/GettyImages-1369144701.jpg?auto=format,compress&q=72&fit=crop)

Lac Gentau and Pic du Midi d'Ossau on the GR10 trekking route. Alex Treadway/Getty Images

5. Pic du Midi, France
----------------------

**Best for stargazing**

 Advertisement 

Scan the heavens on a clear night in the summer and you might witness a spectacular light show: the Perseids meteor shower, sparking dozens of shooting stars in the upper atmosphere. The Perseids are active between mid-July and late August each year, peaking around August 12. Head for a dark-sky reserve where you can also admire the Milky Way in between meteors. The [Pic du Midi](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/france/vallee-des-gaves/attractions/pic-du-midi/a/poi-sig/1233533/1317063), in [the central French Pyrenees,](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/top-things-to-do-in-the-french-pyrenees) is one such reserve, with a historic (now high-spec) observatory at 2877m (9439ft); visit during the day to learn about celestial phenomena and admire the mountain panorama, or at night for an immersive astronomical experience. Even if you don’t make it up to the observatory, this region – popular with skiers in winter but peaceful in summer – offers stellar stargazing opportunities, not to mention tremendous hiking: the GR10 long-distance trail meanders nearby. Find a campsite, mountain refuge or apartment in a quiet village, and simply look to the skies.

**Planning tip:** Shuttle buses travel from Lourdes to La Mongie, from where cable cars run up to the observatory. The nearest airports are at Lourdes/Tarbes, Toulouse and Pau.

![Image 32: A spa town with regal buildings at the foot of lush green hills covered in mountain mist.](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2025-04/shutterstock2288778709.jpg?auto=format,compress&q=72&fit=crop)

Bad Gastein Spa and Ski Resort in summer. aaddyy/Shutterstock

6. Central Austria
------------------

**Best for a spa break**

To find wellness in [Austria](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/austria), look for the Bad in everything – at least, in place names: if it starts Bad, it’s a spa town. A dense cluster of saunas, treatment centers and thermal waters studs a broad swathe of central Austria east and south of [Salzburg](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/austria/salzburg), most with a suitably uplifting backdrop of alpine peaks, meadows and valleys. The focus varies subtly from place to place. In Bad Aussee, expect a healthy diet plus outdoor activity, in line with the concepts of Kneipp therapy. The benefits of brine have been promoted in stately Bad Ischl since it received the imperial seal of approval in the mid-19th century. Natural hot springs feed the action at Bad Gastein, with forest bathing and barefoot walking added to the mix in neighboring Bad Hofgastein, which hosts one of Europe’s largest thermal spa complexes. But you won’t want to stay inside during the long, warm days of summer: roam the picturesque paths circling the Salzkammergut’s sparkling lakes, pedal mountain-bike trails above Bad Gastein, or take an invigorating dip in an alpine tarn.

**Planning tip:**Fly or travel by train to Salzburg, from where most spa towns are accessible by bus or train.

![Image 33: An empty sandy beach with forest on one side and ocean on the other.](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2025-04/shutterstock2513285969.jpg?auto=format,compress&q=72&fit=crop)

Find empty beaches along the Baltic Coast, like near Ventspils. marketa1982/Shutterstock

7. Baltic Coast, Latvia
-----------------------

**Best for empty beaches and national parks**

With some 300km (187 miles) of largely empty shoreline – much of it white sand, backed by wooded hills and ridges – you might wonder why [Latvia’s western coast](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/first-time-guide-to-latvia) isn’t more developed. The answer lies in the communist era, when this was the western Soviet frontier, a strategic area from which locals were squeezed. Today it’s a mesmerizing region to roam on sunny summer days: sometimes somber, sometimes seductive, always spectacular. Coastal settlements range from rapidly gentrifying Ventspils to gritty, grungy Liepāja (great for alternative music) and a host of small fishing villages studding isolated stretches where you’re sure to find a beach all to yourself. To really get away from it all, head north to [Slītere National Park](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/latvia/baltic-coast-road/attractions/slitere-national-park/a/poi-sig/1464988/1339134) and Kolka, the headland where the Baltic meets the Gulf of Rīga. Here, hike or bike among towering dunes, woods and sea, and munch smoked fish bought in traditional fishing villages, such as Vaide, Košrags and Mazirbe, where you can also learn about near-extinct Livonian culture.

**Planning tip:** Most visitors arrive on the west coast from [Rīga](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/latvia/riga); buses trace the coastline to Kolka and run inland to Ventspils and Liepāja, but hiring a car makes travel quicker and easier.

![Image 35: Colorful coal mining houses near the foot of a hill.](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2025-03/shutterstock2360427975.jpg?auto=format,compress&q=72&fit=crop&ar=4:3&w=800&h=600)

**Left:** Arctic fox, Svalbard. JoannaPerchaluk / Shutterstock **Right:** Coal mining houses on the hills of Longyearbyen. LouieLea/Shutterstock

8. Svalbard, Norway
-------------------

**Best for wildlife watching**

In the high Arctic, the window of opportunity for cruising is open only briefly: the northernmost shores and most [remote fjords of the chilly Svalbard archipelago](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/first-time-guide-to-svalbard) are accessible by sea for only a month or two each summer. But it’s a window worth seeking out. In July, the seas are mostly clear of ice, the temperature "soars" to a (relatively) balmy 5°C (41°F) and the sun shines for weeks on end – morning, noon and (mid)night – enabling 24-hour sightseeing. Expedition cruise vessels plow past the islands’ jagged mountains and creaking glaciers, while expert guides keep watch for wildlife: walrus colonies, herds of reindeer, Arctic foxes, seals, whales of all sorts and, of course, polar bears. Perhaps 3000 of the huge white predators stalk Svalbard and the surrounding Arctic region; in summer, when the ice breaks up, the bears stay close to the coast. Board a small Zodiac boat and explore the shoreline for the chance of a close encounter.

**Planning tip:** Fly via [Oslo](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/norway/oslo) to Longyearbyen on Spitsbergen, Svalbard’s main island, from where one- or two-week cruises depart; itineraries and activities are dictated by weather and sea conditions.

![Image 36: Sun loungers and umbrellas dot a beach where people are relaxing in the sunshine.](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2025-03/shutterstock2489143285.jpg?auto=format,compress&q=72&fit=crop)

A beach club in Ksamil on the Albanian Riviera. Hyserb/Shutterstock

9. Albanian Riviera, Albania
----------------------------

**Best for an under-the-radar beach break**

While not quite the hidden gem that it was at the turn of the millennium, when empty beaches and truly bargain prices abounded, [Albania](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/destinations/albania)’s glorious southern shoreline remains a treat for those in search of sun, sand and seafood. Saranda is now a fully fledged party town, its esplanade lined with bars. For quieter resorts, head up the coast to Himara, flanked by a scattering of [good beaches](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/best-beaches-in-albania) (try Potami, just to the south). In summer, you’re guaranteed sun, balmy water and hot tweather; unsurprisingly, loungers and beach umbrellas are at a premium but you can still seek out peaceful patches of sand at spots such as Palasa, Borsh, pebbly Bunec and the islands off Ksamil. Or head over to the epic Llogara Pass to Vlora Bay, where you’ll find more resorts and boat trips to isolated beaches at the end of the Karaburuni Peninsula. For a break from sand-lolling, head to the archaeological site of [Butrint](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/albania/the-albanian-riviera/attractions/butrint/a/poi-sig/1005319/1324728), where Greek, Roman and Byzantine ruins, some dating back 2500 years, are crammed onto a knobbly headland.

**Planning tip:**From Corfu, which receives international fights and ferries from the Italian port of Brindisi, daily fast ferries reach the main city of Saranda in 30 minutes.

![Image 37: A ferry traveling along beside a forest-covered island.](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2025-03/shutterstock1548260474.jpg?auto=format,compress&q=72&fit=crop&ar=4:3&w=800&h=600)

**Left:** A ferry in the Stockholm archipelago. Igor Grochev/Shutterstock **Right:** Gamla Stan in Stockholm. Zuzana Habekova/Shutterstock

![Image 38: Colorful historic buildings and houses in a city old town.](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2025-03/shutterstock2006415956.jpg?auto=format,compress&q=72&fit=crop&ar=1:1&w=450&h=450)

10. Stockholm Archipelago, Sweden
---------------------------------

**Best for an island break**

Less a city, more a wooded archipelago that happens to host some important buildings, [Sweden’s capital](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/destinations/sweden/stockholm) is unreasonably attractive – and never more so than in sunny summer, when the sun glints on the water and the many parks beckon. Stockholm has enough cultural attractions to pack several days, from the cobbled alleys of [Gamla Stan](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/destinations/sweden/stockholm/gamla-stan) (Old Town) to exceptional contemporary galleries and museums (including open-air [Skansen](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/sweden/stockholm/djurgarden-skeppsholmen/attractions/skansen/a/poi-sig/406824/1341999)), while the sleek modern shopping district of Nordmalm offers ample welcoming cafes and restaurants for the all-important fika (coffee and cake break). It’s easy to roam the 14 main islands on foot, by bike or metro, but there are tens of thousands more islets and rocks in the archipelago that are best explored by ferry, on a boat cruise or – better yet – by kayak. Watch for ospreys, beavers and grey seals in various choice spots around the archipelago.

**Planning tip:**Even in summer, bring warm layers for evenings, when temperatures can drop to 10°C (50°F). Things get quieter after the Swedish school summer holidays end in the second half of August.

![Image 39: A beautiful sandy beach and rocky coastline. ](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2025-04/shutterstock2198520695.jpg?auto=format,compress&q=72&fit=crop&ar=1:1&w=450&h=450)

![Image 40: A bottlenose dolphin jumps high from the ocean with cliffs in the distance.](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2025-04/shutterstock2232673829.jpg?auto=format,compress&q=72&fit=crop&ar=4:3&w=800&h=600)

**Left:** Cardigan Bay, Wales. Shutterstock / Richard Whitcombe **Right:** A bottlenose dolphin in Cardigan Bay. Karl Weller/Shutterstock

11. Cardigan Bay, Wales
-----------------------

**Best for sea life**

The coast of west [Wales](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/destinations/wales) is a popular destination – for marine mammals as well as holidaying humans. In summer, the broad sweep of Cardigan Bay hosts Europe’s largest population of bottlenose dolphins, some resident, others seasonal visitors, and numbering around 300 individuals. They’re not shy, and as summer warms up, a boat trip offers a healthy chance of enjoying a close encounter, especially likely offshore of Cemaes Head or New Quay; hop on board from one of the attractive harbors at the southern end of the bay. The fun doesn’t end with dolphins: grey seals haul out on rocks, and you might also spot harbor porpoises and seabirds such as guillemots and razorbills. On land, explore the Dylan Thomas connections at New Quay, roam ancient castles and churches, and fuel up on local treats – seafood, of course, but also excellent artisan cheeses.

**Planning tip:**Base yourself in one of Ceredigion’s postcard-pretty coastal towns – New Quay, Aberaeron or Llangrannog – and spend a few days exploring. The Cardigan to Aberystwyth section (97km/60 miles) of the coastal path makes an achievable four- or five-day adventure.

![Image 41: People wander through a city square lined with tall townhouses](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2025-04/GettyImages-1399548275.jpg?auto=format,compress&q=72&fit=crop)

Square of the Cathedral, Antwerp, in summertime. StefanoZaccaria/Getty Images

12. Antwerp, Belgium
--------------------

**Best for a cultural city break**

Many things in [Antwerp](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/destinations/belgium/flanders/antwerp), the thrumming historical hub of the Low Countries, are high: the culture, the fashion and, in many respects, the prices. Fortunately, summer offers a respite for your wallet via Zomer van Antwerpen (Antwerp Summer), a diverse and densely packed calendar of music, dance, theater and circus performances that takes over the city from late June through August – many events are free, while others charge "democratic" (ie bargain) prices. Of course, there’s plenty more to pack into a short break: Rubens' masterworks in [his house-museum](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/belgium/flanders/antwerp/attractions/rubenshuis/a/poi-sig/425633/358710) and within the spectacular [Onze-Lieve Vrouwekathedraal](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/belgium/flanders/antwerp/attractions/onze-lieve-vrouwekathedraal/a/poi-sig/425595/358710); city-wide medieval and art nouveau architectural gems; hedonistic clubs and summer pop-up bars in parks and along the river. Long renowned as a trading center for diamonds and, more recently, cutting-edge fashion, Antwerp offers dangerously addictive shopping, too.

**Planning tip:**Antwerp’s spectacular fin-de-siècle [Central Station](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/belgium/flanders/antwerp/attractions/antwerpen-centraal/a/poi-sig/425573/358710) is a destination in itself – arrive by train if possible (easy, with ample services from across Europe, many via Brussels). The airport is just 5km (3 miles) southeast of the city center.

13. Julian Alps, Slovenia
-------------------------

**Best for outdoor adventures**

In [Slovenia](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/destinations/slovenia/), a land of spectacular mountains, lakes and rivers, and one of Europe’s most forested countries, it’s no coincidence that Slovenes are so keen on outdoor activities. And [the Julian Alps](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/destinations/slovenia/the-julian-alps), where the 2684m (8806ft) Mt Triglav is surrounded by 840 sq km (324 sq miles) of national park, are the focus of this action. Summer is a great time to get outside, whether swimming in picture-perfect lakes [Bled](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/destinations/slovenia/julian-alps/bled) or [Bohinj](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/destinations/slovenia/julian-alps/bohinj), rafting the Soča River or canyoning the Grmečica gorge. Hiking is also huge here: it’s said that every Slovenian should climb Triglav at least once, but you could also dip into the low-level, circular Julian Alps Trail, totalling 260km (162 miles) and affording tremendous views of the peaks, plus access to village accommodation, cultural insights and places to fuel up on excellent Slovenian cuisine and wines – universally high in quality but low in price.

**Planning tip:** Fly to [Ljubljana](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/destinations/slovenia/ljubljana) or [Venice](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/destinations/italy/venice) (an easy drive west), then either tackle some of the Julian Alps Trail or explore from a handy base – Kobarid or Bovec for the Soča Valley, Kranjska Gora or Mojstrana for the Sava Valley, or any of the settlements in the Bohinj Valley.

# Historical adventurers way more interesting than you

Apr 23, 2014 • 6 min read

At the risk of starting on a bummer note, it's my sad duty to confirm that the age of groundbreaking, Earth-bound adventure is effectively over. Even virtually unknown destinations are now just a search away on Google, and they probably have an active Instagram feed. The only round-the-world challenge left involves travelling on a pogo stick - backwards. Someone, somewhere has already trodden the most remote nooks, crannies and mountaintops; and those places also have decent wi-fi.

But take heart, adventurer: the beautiful thing about travel isn't that you're the first or best or even the worst; it's the personal discovery, growth and fulfilment you glean on the way. You may be the 119,837,857th person to lay eyes on Pompeii, but what counts is how this experience affects and shapes you as an individual.

What follows is a small selection of history's bravest, most determined, craziest adventurers. You'll probably never be as interesting as them, but that doesn't mean you can't ape their adventures and make them - in some sense - your own.

### Erik the Red/Leif Ericson

**Noteworthy adventures:** Settled [Greenland](http://www.lonelyplanet.com/greenland) and (briefly) [North America](http://www.lonelyplanet.com/north-america).

Back when a lot of people still suspected that sailing off into the unknown might end with them dropping off the edge of a flat Earth or blundering into a dragon's lair, it must have taken nerves of steel for this Norwegian father/son duo to blaze a trail to Greenland and North America.

That said, Erik the Red had little choice but to flee [Iceland](http://www.lonelyplanet.com/iceland) and become the first European settler on Greenland in 986 AD because of the murderous fallout of his bad temper. Travel/exploration as a result of banishment ran in the family â Erik's father washed up in Iceland after being invited to leave [Norway](http://www.lonelyplanet.com/norway) for similar reasons.

Leif Ericson, who broke with tradition by murdering no one, pushed further west to find 'Vinland' (known today as Newfoundland), which another merchant sailor had reported sighting after being blown off course. Leif reached land and helped establish settlements around 1000 AD, which were used as a base for shipping timber back to Greenland. For a variety of reasons, all the settlements were abandoned after only a few years.

**Emulate them:** Whether or not you've been banished from your home country, journeying through Newfoundland and Greenland can be an otherworldly, enriching experience even today.

### Ferdinand Magellan

**Noteworthy adventures:** Organized the first circumnavigation of Earth.

While acting on a disastrous hunch about a shorter, westerly route from [Europe](http://www.lonelyplanet.com/europe) to the Spice Islands in [Indonesia](http://www.lonelyplanet.com/indonesia), Portuguese-born Magellan inadvertently organized the first circumnavigation of the Earth. He doesn't get much credit, though. This is because he and most of his crew didn't complete the journey thanks to mutiny - and associated punitive executions - abandonment, wars, disease, and starvation.

The journey was eventually completed by forgiven mutineer Juan SebastiÃ¡n Elcano after Magellan was killed in the [Philippines](http://www.lonelyplanet.com/philippines). Of the five ships and 270 men that set off from [Seville](http://www.lonelyplanet.com/spain/seville) in August of 1519, only one beat-up, spice-laden ship carrying just 18 men from the original crew limped back to [Spain](http://www.lonelyplanet.com/spain) in September 1522. Other abandoned stragglers eventually made their way home, bringing the survivor count to roughly 38.

Though he didn't get the fame, fortune and shortcut to the Spice Islands that he envisioned, Magellan's mission greatly expanded Europe's knowledge of the world, including the accidental discovery of the Pacific Ocean, and revealed how the planet was quite a bit larger than anyone had previously suspected. Also, though it had long been suggested that the Earth was probably not flat, this misadventure was the first empirical proof of a spherical world.

**Emulate him:** A round-the-world sailing trip is never dull or ordinary. And if the potential for mutiny, abandonment, wars, disease, and starvation fits your idea of adventure travel, you can always book a couple of flights on a budget airline.

### Ibn Battuta

**Noteworthy adventures:** Clocked up an impressive 73,000 miles during the 14th century.

While most of the people listed here traveled with a pretty specific goal in mind, Ibn Battuta just had the urge to wander. And boy did he do that.

A Berber from [Morocco](http://www.lonelyplanet.com/morocco), Battuta originally left home to undertake a meandering pilgrimage to Mecca. From there, he just kept on going. Over nearly 30 years (1325-1354) he traveled some 73,000 miles, visiting [Cairo](http://www.lonelyplanet.com/egypt/cairo), Mogadishu, the Arabian Peninsula, Iraq, Constantinople, Bulgaria, Central Asia, [India](http://www.lonelyplanet.com/india), Sri Lanka, the Maldives, Indonesia, Vietnam, Beijing, [Sardinia](http://www.lonelyplanet.com/italy/sardinia), Spain, Timbuktu and then back home without, obviously, the help of any motorized transport. He stopped frequently to work, rub shoulders with the rich, famous and powerful of the era, marry a few no doubt long-suffering ladies, stumble into various adventures/trouble and recover from what must have been some truly horrific bouts of traveler's diarrhea.

Accounts of Battuta's travels - dictated from memory as he didn't keep a journal - were later published in the Rihla ('The Journey').

**Emulate him:** Overland, self-powered travel is a small but inherently badass niche. Even short trips can be fulfilling and inspire awe from friends and bystanders.

### Nellie Bly

**Noteworthy adventures:** First 'almost unchaperoned' round-the-world trip by a woman.

At the age of 25, celebrated journalist Elizabeth Jane Cochrane, writing under the pen name Nellie Bly, set out on 14 November, 1889, to emulate Jules Verne's fictional character Phileas Fogg in *Around the World in Eighty Days*. She completed the (obviously) overland trip on 25 January 1890, in a world-record time of 72 days, six hours, 11 minutes and 14 seconds. (Her record was broken by some killjoy man just a few months later.) Bly traveled 'with nothing but the dress on her back, a heavy coat, a few pairs of underwear, and a small bag carrying her toiletries'.

Bly's easterly route via steamships and railways started in New Jersey, went through [England](http://www.lonelyplanet.com/england), France (where she actually met Jules Verne), down to Brindisi, [Italy](http://www.lonelyplanet.com/italy), through the Suez Canal, Sri Lanka, Malaysia, Singapore, Hong Kong, [China](http://www.lonelyplanet.com/china) and Japan before landing on US soil in San Francisco and completing the trip on a chartered private train back to New Jersey.

**Emulate her:** Overland, round-the-world trips are infinitely more comfortable these days, but that doesn't mean they aren't ambitious and fulfilling.

### Dervla Murphy

**Noteworthy adventures:** self-supported bike trip from [Ireland](http://www.lonelyplanet.com/ireland) to India in 1963.

Murphy started what would be decades of tireless adventure travel and writing with this pedal-powered quest, which took her through the teeth of Europe during an especially bad winter, followed by Iran, [Afghanistan](http://www.lonelyplanet.com/afghanistan), and Pakistan. Armed with a near imperviousness to discomfort, a disregard for personal safety, and a .25 pistol, which was put to use fending off hungry wolves in Bulgaria and 'lecherous Kurds in Persia', she achieved her objective mostly unscathed and wrote about the adventure in the memoir *Full Tilt: Ireland to India With a Bicycle*.

**Emulate her:** Travel by bike is a surefire way to get a more intimate look at destinations and cultures.
